columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the rights offerings.

The **right offering** is a public offering of shares in which existing shareholders are initially given securities. There is no additional stock issued in a rights issue, lowering a present company's ownership proportion as long as the existing shareholder exercises all of his rights to maintain an equal proportion shareholding by subscribing to new share financings at or below market rates.

Let us first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Shares outstanding| 375,000|
|Share price, shares outstanding| $67.00| 
|New shares |50,000|
|Share price, new shares |$58.00|

The new market value is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New market value}&={\text{(SO $\times$ SP) + (New shares $\times$ SP)}}\\

\end{aligned}$$ 

Where: 

SO = Shares outstanding 

SP = Share price

## B. 

Then, let us compute the number of rights associated with one of the new shares. This is computed by dividing the shares outstanding by the number of new shares. This is computed as follows: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of rights }&=\dfrac{\text{Shares outstanding}}{\text{New shares}}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{375,000}}{\text{50,000}}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{7.50}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The number of rights required to buy a share of stock is 7.50 rights.**

## C. 

Next, let us determine the ex-rights price by dividing the new market value of the company that we have computed from step 4 by the total number of shares. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Ex-rights price }&=\dfrac{\text{New market value}}{\text{Total number of shares after issue }}\\[10pt]
&=\dfrac{\text{\$28,025,000.00}}{\text{425,000 }}\\[10pt]
&={\textbf{\$65.94}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The value of each share will decline by $65.94 after the rights offering.**

## D. 

Now, let's determine the value of a right by subtracting the market price per share by the ex-right price per share we have computed from step 6. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of the right}&={\text{(Market value per share) - (Ex-right price per share)}}\\
&={\text{\$67.00 - \$65.94}}\\
&={\textbf{\$1.06}}
\end{aligned}$$ 

**The value of one right amounts to $1.06.**

## E. 


The firm has a rights offering rather than a general cash offer because the right offering is a less expensive option. This safeguards current stockholders' proportional interests and prevents underpricing. This is also the most cost-effective way for the firm to raise funds. Stockholders are given preference by providing more firm securities at a lower than the market price.
